bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sol Feinstone, born Solomon Bialagrudsky in 1888 in Lithuania, migrated to the United States in 1902. A socialist, he became a successful businessman and a collector of historical documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence between Sol Feinstone and Roman Rosdolsky, primarily in connection with a 337-page manuscript relating to Rosdolsky's "Friedrich Engeles und das Problem der Geschichtslosen Volker" with a four-page English summary. This manuscript was first published in German in 1964 as Friedrich Engels und das Problem der "Geschictsloen" Volker (Die Nationalitatenfrage inder Revolution 1849-1849 im Lichte der "Neuen Rheinischen Zeitung"); , and in English in 1986 as Engels and the "Nonhistoric" Peoples: The National Question in the Revolution of 1848; and twenty-eight documents including signed letters by Edward Bellamy, Eugene V. Debs, Petr Kropotkin; page of notes in French by Karl Marx; and surveyor's report (1770) of Blidworth, England; and other papers of 17 people, most associated with the French Revolution. Individuals represented in the collection include: Bellamy, Edward, 1850-1898; Debs, Eugene V.
